item.title: Where Is the iPod of Smartwatches?
item.description:
Where Is the iPod of Smartwatches?

The lifecycle of a new gadget is relatively predictable: When it's brand new, only early adopters are interested. Once the technology matures, everybody buys one. But smartwatches still haven't caught on with most people-and that's because no one has made a smartwatch that's worth its cost.

item.title: A groundbreaking technology will soon let us see exactly what is in our food
item.description:
A groundbreaking technology will soon let us see exactly what is in our food

I have seen the future of food transparency, and it is optical. Also, it fits in your smartphone. Imagine a scanner the size of a grain of rice, built into your phone. You go to the grocery store and point it at something you want to buy.

item.title: Report: Google's placing its own bet on mobile livestreaming with YouTube Connect
item.description:
Report: Google's placing its own bet on mobile livestreaming with YouTube Connect

It looks like livestreaming is becoming a thing again. In the wake of Twitter's desire to build out Periscope and Facebook's eagerness to push Live Videos to the masses, it seems Google does not want to be left behind. According to a report from VentureBeat, which cited a source, Google has built its own livestreaming feature called YouTube Connect.

item.title: Gmail will now warn you if you're being targeted by the government
item.description:
Gmail will now warn you if you're being targeted by the government

Apple isn't the only company fighting against government-backed cyber attacks. While Apple and the FBI bicker over user security, Google is bringing security into the public eye in a different way - by simply telling you what's going on.

AT&T's Wi-Fi Calling Is Now a Cheap Way to Phone Home From Overseas

item.title: As Apple Doubles Down on Encrypted Phones, Google Sits on Its Design for a "Digital Safe"
item.description:
As Apple Doubles Down on Encrypted Phones, Google Sits on Its Design for a "Digital Safe"

A memory card developed by Google that upgrades a smartphone with strongly encrypted messaging and storage could improve security and trouble law enforcement. As Apple faces criticism from the FBI for refusing to help law enforcement break into iPhones, rival Google is sitting on technology that would upgrade existing mobile devices with an encrypted "digital safe" that secures data, messages, and video and voice calls.
